Cell.Data: This LBD module was coded by Greg Neils & David Merle at the Data Coordinating Center at Columbia University.
Please contact Greg, gn2003@cumc.columbia.edu, with any updates/bugs that you find in this code book.
Subject: Re: NACC UDS @ Columbia University
We've tested and improved the skip patterns.
We also caught some basic HTML mistakes in our coding and fixed them.
Please throw away the last code book and use this one.
Nobody likes fixing someone else's mistakes!
this version does have the corrected 2a-2d descriptors
I also added some text into the Header Instrument.
It is a basic nod to David Merle and myself.
It includes my email to so people can send fixes and bugs.
There are direction in the header to remove the "read me" text.

ss:Data.Font: Form change to clarify LBD Module Form C1L (Noise Pareidolia Test scores)

Cell.Data: On Form C1L, the descriptors for items 2a - 2d have been clarified and made consistent in
the form, neuropsych worksheet, and guidebook. The descriptors now read:
The revised documents are now posted on the NACC website. Please be sure that your Center is using the current version.
Updated version by M. Emily Merrill
(Took initial forms as template, changed header, footer, and questions as needed, prefix of fu_ for variable names and matrix group)
Added option to questions on follow-up forms: "777, 777 Provided at previous visit" and Updated Field Note to include new option (777=Provided at previous visit; 888=Not applicable; 999=Unknown)
Form B3L in the Follow-Up Visit Packet mentions the coding guidebook in the initial visit, not the follow up. Typo?
B8L (Initial and Follow Up) added the "Adapted/Permission" paragraphs into footer.
E1L, Follow-Up: added question 1, which is not on the Initial Vist Form, and added branching for it.

INITIAL VISIT PACKET NACC Uniform Data Set (UDS) LBD Module Form B1L: Clinical Symptoms and Exam INSTRUCTIONS: This form is to be completed by a clinician or other trained health professional. For additional clarification and examples, see LBD Module Coding Guidebook for Initial Visit Packet, Form B1L. Check only one box per question. AUTONOMIC SYMPTOMS CHECKLIST In the past six months...
1. Does the participant dribble saliva during the day?
2. Does the participant have difficulty swallowing?
3. Does the participant have altered interest in sex?
4. Does the participant have problems having sex?
5. Does the participant have a recent change in weight (not related to dieting)?
6. Does the participant report a change in the ability to taste or smell?
7. Does the participant experience excessive sweating (not related to hot weather)?
8. Does the participant report having difficulty tolerating cold weather?
9. Does the participant report having difficulty tolerating hot weather?
10. Does the participant experience double vision (two separate real objects, and not blurred vision)?
11. Does the participant have problems with constipation?
12. Does the participant have to strain to pass hard stools?
13. Has the participant had involuntary loss of stools?
14. Has the participant had the feeling that after passing urine, their bladder was not completely empty?
15. Has the participant's stream of urine been weak or reduced?
16. Has the participant had to pass urine within two hours of the previous urination?
17. Has the participant complained of feeling light-headed or dizzy when standing up?
18. Has the participant become light-headed after standing for some time?
20. Indicate the first predominant symptom to appear during the participant's lifetime: (SELECT ONLY ONE)

1, 1 Dribbling saliva during the day | 2, 2 Difficulty swallowing | 3, 3 Altered interest in sex | 4, 4 Problems having sex | 5, 5 Recent change in weight not related to dieting | 6, 6 Change in ability to taste or smell | 7, 7 Excessive sweating | 8, 8 Difficulty tolerating cold weather | 9, 9 Difficulty tolerating hot weather | 10, 10 Double vision | 11, 11 Constipation | 12, 12 Straining to pass hard stools | 13, 13 Involuntary loss of stools | 14, 14 Feeling after passing urine that bladder is not completely empty | 15, 15 Stream of urine is weak or reduced | 16, 16 Passing urine within two hours of previous urination | 17, 17 Feeling light-headed or dizzy when standing up | 18, 18 Feeling light-headed after standing for some time | 19, 19 Fainting | 88, 88 Not applicable - never experienced any of these symptoms | 99, 99 Unknown
21. At what age did the first predominant symptom appear?
<font size="3" color="blue">AGE OF ONSET OF NON-MOTOR SYMPTOMS</font>
28. Age of onset of probable REM sleep behavior disorder
29. Age of onset of impaired smell
<font size="3" color="blue">AGE OF ONSET OF MOTOR SYMPTOMS</font>
30. Age of onset of gait disorder
34. Was a standardized scale of autonomic symptoms completed at this visit?
0, 0 No (END FORM HERE) | 1, Yes (CONTINUE TO QUESTIONS 34a and 34b)
34b. If yes: what was the score

Form B2L: UPDRS Part II - Activities of Daily Living (Determine for "On/Off") INSTRUCTIONS: This form is to be completed by the clinician or other trained health professional. For additional clarification and examples, see LBD Module Coding Guidebook for Initial Visit Packet, Form B2L. Check only one box per question.

0, 0 Normal. | 1, 1 Mildly affected. No difficulty being understood. | 2, 2 Moderately affected. Sometimes asked to repeat statements. | 3, 3 Severely affected. Frequently asked to repeat statements. | 4, 4 Unintelligible most of the time. | 8, 8 Not applicable. | 9, 9 Unknown.

0, 0 Normal. | 1, 1 Slight but definite excess of saliva in mouth; may have night time drooling. | 2, 2 Moderately excessive saliva; may have minimal drooling. | 3, 3 Marked excess of saliva with some drooling. | 4, 4 Marked drooling, requires constant tissue or handkerchief. | 8, 8 Not applicable. | 9, 9 Unknown.
0, 0 Normal. | 1, 1 Rare choking. | 2, 2 Occasional choking. | 3, 3 Requires soft food. | 4, 4 Requires NG tube or gastrotomy feeding. | 8, 8 Not applicable. | 9, 9 Unknown.

0, 0 Normal. | 1, 1 Slightly slow or small. | 2, 2 Moderately slow or small; all words are legible. | 3, 3 Severely affected; not all words are legible. | 4, 4 The majority of words are not legible. | 8, 8 Not applicable. | 9, 9 Unknown.
<font size="3">5. Cutting food and handling utensils</font>

0, 0 Normal. | 1, 1 Somewhat slow and clumsy, but no help needed. | 2, 2 Can cut most foods, although clumsy and slow; some help needed. | 3, 3 Food must be cut by someone, but can still feed slowly. | 4, 4 Needs to be fed. | 8, 8 Not applicable. | 9, 9 Unknown.

0, 0 Normal. | 1, 1 Somewhat slow, but no help needed. | 2, 2 Occasional assistance with buttoning, getting arms in sleeves. | 3, 3 Considerable help required, but can do some things alone. | 4, 4 Helpless. | 8, 8 Not applicable. | 9, 9 Unknown.

0, 0 Normal. | 1, 1 Somewhat slow, but no help needed. | 2, 2 Needs help to shower or bathe; or very slow in hygienic care. | 3, 3 Requires assistance for washing/brushing teeth/combing hair/going to bathroom. | 4, 4 Foley catheter or other mechanical aids. | 8, 8 Not applicable. | 9, 9 Unknown.
<font size="3">8. Turning in bed and adjusting bedclothes </font>

0, 0 Normal. | 1, 1 Somewhat slow and clumsy, but no help needed. | 2, 2 Can turn alone or adjust sheets, but with great difficulty. | 3, 3 Can initiate, but not turn or adjust sheets alone. | 4, 4 Helpless. | 8, 8 Not applicable. | 9, 9 Unknown.
0, 0 None. | 1, 1 Rare falling. | 2, 2 Occasionally falls, less than once per day. | 3, 3 Fall an average of once daily. | 4, 4 Falls more than once daily. | 8, 8 Not applicable. | 9, 9 Unknown.

0, 0 None. | 1, 1 Rare freezing when walking; may have start-hesitation. | 2, 2 Occasional freezing when walking. | 3, 3 Frequent freezing. Occasionally falls from freezing. | 4, 4 Frequent falls from freezing. | 8, 8 Not applicable. | 9, 9 Unknown.

0, 0 Normal. | 1, 1 Mild difficulty. May not swing arms or may tend to drag leg. | 2, 2 Moderate difficulty, but requires little or no assistance. | 3, 3 Severe disturbance of walking, requiring assistance. | 4, 4 Cannot walk at all, even with assistance. | 8, 8 Not applicable. | 9, 9 Unknown.

0, 0 Absent. | 1, 1 Slight and infrequently present. | 2, 2 Moderate; bothersome to participant. | 3, 3 Severe; interferes with many activities. | 4, 4 Marked; interferes with most activities. | 8, 8 Not applicable. | 9, 9 Unknown.
<font size = '3'>13. Sensory complaints related to Parkinsonism </font>

0, 0 None. | 1, 1 Occasionally has numbness, tingling, or mild aching. | 2, 2 Frequently has numbness, tingling, or aching; not distressing. | 3, 3 Frequent painful sensations. | 4, 4 Excruciating pain. | 8, 8 Not applicable. | 9, 9 Unknown.

National Alzheimer's Coordinating Center | (206) 543-8637 | fax: (206) 616-5927 | naccmail@uw.edu | www.alz.washington.edu LBD Module (Aug 2017), UDS (v3.0, March 2015) Initial Visit Form B2L: UPDRS Part II - Activities of Daily Living

Form B3L: UPDRS Part III - Motor Examination 1 INSTRUCTIONS: This form is to be completed by the clinician or other trained health professional. For additional clarification and examples, see LBD Module Coding Guidebook for Initial Visit Packet, Form B3L. Check only one box per question.

0, 0 Normal. | 1, 1 Slight loss of expression, diction, and/or volume. | 2, 2 Monotone, slurred but understandable; moderately impaired. | 3, 3 Marked impairment, difficult to understand. | 4, 4 Unintelligible. | 8, 8 Untestable.

0, 0 Normal. | 1, 1 Minimal hypomimia, could be normal poker face. | 2, 2 Slight but definitely abnormal diminution of facial expression. | 3, 3 Moderate hypomimia; lips parted some of the time. | 4, 4 Masked or fixed facies with severe or complete loss of facial expression; lips parted 1/4 inch or more | 8, 8 Untestable.
<font size = "3">3a. Tremor at rest - face: lips: chin</font>

0, 0 Absent. | 1, 1 Slight and infrequently present. | 2, 2 Mild in amplitude and persistent. Or moderate in amplitude, but only intermittently present. | 3, 3 Moderate in amplitude and present most of the time. | 4, 4 Marked in amplitude and present most of the time. | 8, 8 Untestable.
<font size = "3">3b. Tremor at rest - right hand</font>

0, 0 Absent. | 1, 1 Slight and infrequently present. | 2, 2 Mild in amplitude and persistent. Or moderate in amplitude, but only intermittently present. | 3, 3 Moderate in amplitude and present most of the time. | 4, 4 Marked in amplitude and present most of the time. | 8, 8 Untestable.
<font size = "3">3c. Tremor at rest - left hand</font>

0, 0 Absent. | 1, 1 Slight and infrequently present. | 2, 2 Mild in amplitude and persistent. Or moderate in amplitude, but only intermittently present. | 3, 3 Moderate in amplitude and present most of the time. | 4, 4 Marked in amplitude and present most of the time. | 8, 8 Untestable.
<font size = "3">3d. Tremor at rest - right foot</font>

0, 0 Absent. | 1, 1 Slight and infrequently present. | 2, 2 Mild in amplitude and persistent. Or moderate in amplitude, but only intermittently present. | 3, 3 Moderate in amplitude and present most of the time. | 4, 4 Marked in amplitude and present most of the time. | 8, 8 Untestable.
<font size = "3">3e. Tremor at rest - left foot</font>

0, 0 Absent. | 1, 1 Slight and infrequently present. | 2, 2 Mild in amplitude and persistent. Or moderate in amplitude, but only intermittently present. | 3, 3 Moderate in amplitude and present most of the time. | 4, 4 Marked in amplitude and present most of the time. | 8, 8 Untestable.
<font size = "3" color="blue">4. Action or postural tremor of hands</font>

0, 0 Absent. | 1, 1 Slight; present with action. | 2, 2 Moderate in amplitude, present with action. | 3, 3 Moderate in amplitude with posture holding as well as action. | 4, 4 Marked in amplitude; interferes with feeding. | 8, 8 Untestable.

0, 0 Absent. | 1, 1 Slight; present with action. | 2, 2 Moderate in amplitude, present with action. | 3, 3 Moderate in amplitude with posture holding as well as action. | 4, 4 Marked in amplitude; interferes with feeding. | 8, 8 Untestable.
5. Rigidity (Judged on passive movement of major joints with participant relaxed in sitting position. Cogwheeling to be ignored.)

0, 0 Absent. | 1, 1 Slight or detectable only when activated by mirror or other movements. | 2, 2 Mild to moderate. | 3, 3 Marked, but full range of motion easily achieved. | 4, 4 Severe, range of motion achieved with difficulty. | 8, 8 Untestable.

0, 0 Absent. | 1, 1 Slight or detectable only when activated by mirror or other movements. | 2, 2 Mild to moderate. | 3, 3 Marked, but full range of motion easily achieved. | 4, 4 Severe, range of motion achieved with difficulty. | 8, 8 Untestable.

0, 0 Absent. | 1, 1 Slight or detectable only when activated by mirror or other movements. | 2, 2 Mild to moderate. | 3, 3 Marked, but full range of motion easily achieved. | 4, 4 Severe, range of motion achieved with difficulty. | 8, 8 Untestable.

0, 0 Absent. | 1, 1 Slight or detectable only when activated by mirror or other movements. | 2, 2 Mild to moderate. | 3, 3 Marked, but full range of motion easily achieved. | 4, 4 Severe, range of motion achieved with difficulty. | 8, 8 Untestable.

0, 0 Absent. | 1, 1 Slight or detectable only when activated by mirror or other movements. | 2, 2 Mild to moderate. | 3, 3 Marked, but full range of motion easily achieved. | 4, 4 Severe, range of motion achieved with difficulty. | 8, 8 Untestable.
6. Finger taps (Participant taps thumb with index finger in rapid succession with widest amplitude possible, each hand separately.)

0, 0 Normal. | 1, 1 Mild slowing and/or reduction in amplitude. | 2, 2 Moderately impaired. Definite and early fatiguing. May have occasional arrests in movement. | 3, 3 Severely impaired. Frequent hesitation in initiating movements or arrests in ongoing movement. | 4, 4 Can barely perform the task. | 8, 8 Untestable.

0, 0 Normal. | 1, 1 Mild slowing and/or reduction in amplitude. | 2, 2 Moderately impaired. Definite and early fatiguing. May have occasional arrests in movement. | 3, 3 Severely impaired. Frequent hesitation in initiating movements or arrests in ongoing movement. | 4, 4 Can barely perform the task. | 8, 8 Untestable.

0, 0 Normal. | 1, 1 Mild slowing and/or reduction in amplitude. | 2, 2 Moderately impaired. Definite and early fatiguing. May have occasional arrests in movement. | 3, 3 Severely impaired. Frequent hesitation in initiating movements or arrests in ongoing movement. | 4, 4 Can barely perform the task. | 8, 8 Untestable.

0, 0 Normal. | 1, 1 Mild slowing and/or reduction in amplitude. | 2, 2 Moderately impaired. Definite and early fatiguing. May have occasional arrests in movement. | 3, 3 Severely impaired. Frequent hesitation in initiating movements or arrests in ongoing movement. | 4, 4 Can barely perform the task. | 8, 8 Untestable.
8. Rapid alternating movements of hands (Pronation-supination movements of hands, vertically or horizontally, with as large an amplitude as possible, both hands simultaneously.)
<font size = "3">8a. Rapid alternating movement of hands - Right hand</font>

0, 0 Normal. | 1, 1 Mild slowing and/or reduction in amplitude. | 2, 2 Moderately impaired. Definite and early fatiguing. May have occasional arrests in movement. | 3, 3 Severely impaired. Frequent hesitation in initiating movements or arrests in ongoing movement. | 4, 4 Can barely perform the task. | 8, 8 Untestable.
<font size = "3">8b. Rapid alternating movement of hands - Left hand</font>

0, 0 Normal. | 1, 1 Mild slowing and/or reduction in amplitude. | 2, 2 Moderately impaired. Definite and early fatiguing. May have occasional arrests in movement. | 3, 3 Severely impaired. Frequent hesitation in initiating movements or arrests in ongoing movement. | 4, 4 Can barely perform the task. | 8, 8 Untestable.
9. Leg agility (Participant taps heel on ground in rapid succession, picking up entire leg. Amplitude should be about 3 inches.)

0, 0 Normal. | 1, 1 Mild slowing and/or reduction in amplitude. | 2, 2 Moderately impaired. Definite and early fatiguing. May have occasional arrests in movement. | 3, 3 Severely impaired. Frequent hesitation in initiating movements or arrests in ongoing movement. | 4, 4 Can barely perform the task. | 8, 8 Untestable.

0, 0 Normal. | 1, 1 Mild slowing and/or reduction in amplitude. | 2, 2 Moderately impaired. Definite and early fatiguing. May have occasional arrests in movement. | 3, 3 Severely impaired. Frequent hesitation in initiating movements or arrests in ongoing movement. | 4, 4 Can barely perform the task. | 8, 8 Untestable.
10. Arising from chair (Participant attempts to arise from a straight-back wood or metal chair with arms folded across chest.)

0, 0 Normal. | 1, 1 Slow; or may need more than one attempt. | 2, 2 Pushes self up from arms of seat. | 3, 3 Tends to fall back and may have to try more than one time, but can get up without help. | 4, 4 Unable to arise without help. | 8, 8 Untestable.

0, 0 Normal erect. | 1, 1 Not quite erect, slightly stooped posture; could be normal for older person. | 2, 2 Moderately stooped posture, definitely abnormal; can be slightly leaning to one side. | 3, 3 Severely stooped posture with kyphosis; can be moderately leaning to one side. | 4, 4 Marked flexion with extreme abnormality of posture. | 8, 8 Untestable.

0, 0 Normal. | 1, 1 Walks slowly, may shuffle with short steps, but no festination or propulsion. | 2, 2 Walks with difficulty, but requires little or no assistance; may have some festination, short steps, or propulsion. | 3, 3 Severe disturbance of gait, requiring assistance. | 4, 4 Cannot walk at all, even with assistance. | 8, 8 Untestable.
13. Postural stability (Response to sudden posterior displacement produced by pull on shoulders while participant erect with eyes open and feet slightly apart. Participant is prepared.)

0, 0 Normal. | 1, 1 Retropulsion, but recovers unaided. | 2, 2 Absence of postural response; would fall if not caught by examiner. | 3, 3 Very unstable, tends to lose balance spontaneously. | 4, 4 Unable to stand without assistance. | 8, 8 Untestable.
14. Body bradykinesia and hypokinesia (Combining slowness, hesitancy, decreased armswing, small amplitude, and poverty of movement in general.)

0, 0 None. | 1, 1 Minimal slowness, giving movement a deliberate character; could be normal for some persons. Possibly reduced amplitude. | 2, 2 Mild degree of slowness and poverty of movement which is definitely abnormal. Alternatively, some reduced amplitude. | 3, 3 Moderate slowness, poverty, or small amplitude of movement. | 4, 4 Marked slowness, poverty, or small amplitude of movement. | 8, 8 Untestable.
<font size = "3">15. Modified Hoehn and Yahr staging</font>

0, 0 Stage 0 = No signs of disease. | 1, 1 Stage 1 = Unilateral disease. | 2, 2 Stage 1.5 = Unilateral plus axial involvement. | 3, 3 Stage 2 = Bilateral disease, without impairment of balance. | 4, 4 Stage 2.5 = Mild bilateral disease, with recovery on pull test. | 5, 5 Stage 3 = Mild to moderate bilateral disease; some postural instability. | 6, 6 Stage 4 = Severe disability; still able to walk or stand unassisted. | 7, 7 Stage 5 = Wheelchair-bound or bedridden unless aided. | 8, 8 Untestable.

National Alzheimer's Coordinating Center | (206) 543-8637 | fax: (206) 616-5927 | naccmail@uw.edu | www.alz.washington.edu LBD Module (Aug 2017), UDS (v3.0, March 2015) Initial Visit Form B3L: UPDRS Part III - Motor Examination

Form B4L: Neuropsychiatric Inventory (NPI)1
INSTRUCTIONS: This form is to be completed by a clinician or other trained health professional based on co-participant interview. For additional clarification and examples, see LBD Module Coding Guidebook for Initial Visit Packet, Form B4L. Check only one box per question. Inquire about symptoms the last four weeks before visit.

1. Does the participant have beliefs that you know are not true (for example, insisting that people are trying to harm him/her or steal from him/her)? Has he/she said that family members are not who they say they are or that the house is not their home? I'm not asking about mere suspiciousness; I am interested if the participant is convinced that these things are happening to him/her.
0, 0 No (Skip to Question 2) | 1, 1 Yes (COMPLETE Questions 1a - 1l) | 8, 8 Not applicable (Skip to Question 2)
1a. Does the participant believe that he/she is in danger - that others are planning to hurt him/her?
1b. Does the participant believe that others are stealing from him/her?
1c. Does the participant believe that his / her spouse is having an affair?
1d. Does the participant believe that unwelcome guests are living in his/her house?
1e. Does the participant believe that his / her spouse or others are not who they claim to be?
1f. Does the participant believe that his / her house is not his / her home?
1g. Does the participant believe that family members plan to abandon him/her?
1h. Does the participant believe that television or magazine figures are actually present in the home? [Does he/she try to talk or interact with them?]
1i. Does the participant believe any other unusual things that I haven't asked about?

1j. If the screening question is confirmed, determine the frequency and severity of the delusions.
FREQUENCY

1, 1 Mild - delusions present but seem harmless and produce little distress in the participant | 2, 2 Moderate - delusions are distressing and disruptive | 3, 3 Marked - delusions are very disruptive and are a major source of behavioral disruption (if PRN medications are prescribed, their use signals that the delusions are of marked severity)
1l. How emotionally distressing do you find this behavior?
0, 0 Not at all | 1, 1 Minimally | 2, 2 Mildly | 3, 3 Moderately | 4, 4 Severely | 5, 5 Very severely

2. Does the participant have hallucinations such as seeing false visions or hearing imaginary voices? Does he/she seem to see, hear, or experience things that are not present? By this question, we do not mean just mistaken beliefs such as stating that someone who has died is still alive; rather we are asking if the participant actually has abnormal experiences of sounds or visions.
0, 0 No (Skip to Question 3) | 1, 1 Yes (COMPLETE Questions 2a - 2j) | 8, 8 Not applicable (Skip to Question 3)
2a. Does the participant describe hearing voices or acts if he/she hears voices?
2b. Does the participant talk to people who are not there?
2c. Does the participant describe seeing things not seen by others or behave as if he/she is seeing things not seen by others?
2d. Does the participant report smelling odors not smelled by others?
2e. Does the participant describe feeling things on his / her skin or otherwise appear to be feeling things crawling or touching him/her?
2f. Does the participant describe tastes that are without any known cause?
2g. Does the participant describe any other unusual sensory experiences?
1, 1 Occasionally - less than once per week | 2, 2 Often - about once per week | 3, 3 Frequently - several times per week but less than every day | 4, 4 Very frequently - once or more per day

1, 1 Mild - hallucinations are present but seem harmless and cause little distress for the participant | 2, 2 Moderate - hallucinations are distressing and are disruptive to the participant | 3, 3 Marked - hallucinations are very disruptive and are a major source of behavioral disturbance. PRN medications may be required to control them.
2j. How emotionally distressing do you find this behavior?
0, 0 Not at all | 1, 1 Minimally | 2, 2 Mildly | 3, 3 Moderately | 4, 4 Severely | 5, 5 Very severely or extremely
3. Is the participant very nervous, worried, or frightened for no apparent reason? Does he/she seem very tense or fidgety? Is the participant afraid to be apart from you?
0, 0 No (Skip to Question 4 | 1, 1 Yes (COMPLETE Questions 3a - 3j) | 8, 8 Not applicable (Skip to Question 4)
3a. Does the participant say that he/she is worried about planned events?
3b. Does the participant have periods of feeling shaky, unable to relax, or feeling excessively tense?
3c. Does the participant have periods of (or complain of) shortness of breath, gasping, or sighing for no apparent reason other than nervousness?
3d. Does the participant complain of butterflies in his / her stomach, or of racing or pounding of the heart in association with nervousness (symptoms not explained by ill health)?
3e. Does the participant avoid certain places or situations that make him/her more nervous such as riding in the car, meeting with friends, or being in crowds?
3f. Does the participant become nervous and upset when separated from you [or his/her caregiver]? [Does he/she cling to you to keep from being separated?]
3g. Does the participant show any other signs of anxiety?
1, 1 Occasionally - less than once per week | 2, 2 Often - about once per week | 3, 3 Frequently - several times per week but less than every day | 4, 4 Very frequently - once or more per day

1, 1 Mild - anxiety is distressing but usually responds to redirection or reassurance | 2, 2 Moderate - anxiety is distressing, anxiety symptoms are spontaneously voiced by the participant and difficult to alleviate | 3, 3 Marked - anxiety is very distressing and a major source of suffering for the participant
3j. How emotionally distressing do you find this behavior?
0, 0 Not at all | 1, 1 Minimally | 2, 2 Mildly | 3, 3 Moderately | 4, 4 Severely | 5, 5 Very severely or extremely

4. Has the participant lost interest in the world around him/her? Has he/she lost interest in doing things or lack motivation for starting new activities? Is he/she more difficult to engage in conversation or in doing chores? Is the participant apathetic or indifferent?
0, 0 No (SKIP TO QUESTION 5) | 1, 1 Yes (COMPLETE Questions 4a - 4k) | 8, 8 Not applicable (Skip to Question 5)
4a. Does the participant seem less spontaneous and less active than usual?
4b. Is the participant less likely to initiate a conversation?
4c. Is the participant less affectionate or lacking in emotions when compared to his / her usual self?
4d. Does the participant contribute less to household chores?
4e. Does the participant seem less interested in the activities and plans of others?
4f. Has the participant lost interest in friends and family members?
4g. Is the participant less enthusiastic about his / her usual interests?
4h. Does the participant show any other signs that he/she doesn't care about doing new things?

If the screening question is confirmed, determine the frequency and severity of the pathy/indifference.
4i. FREQUENCY
1, 1 Occasionally - less than once per week | 2, 2 Often - about once per week | 3, 3 Frequently - several times per week but less than every day | 4, 4 Very frequently - nearly always present

1, 1 Mild - apathy is notable but produces little interference with daily routines; only mildly different from participant's usual behavior; participant responds to suggestions to engage in activities | 2, 2 Moderate - apathy is very evident; may be overcome by the caregiver with coaxing and encouragement; responds spontaneously only to powerful events such as visits from close relatives or family members | 3, 3 Marked - apathy is very evident and usually fails to respond to any encouragement or external events
4k. How emotionally distressing do you find this behavior?
0, 0 Not at all | 1, 1 Minimally | 2, 2 Mildly | 3, 3 Moderately | 4, 4 Severely | 5, 5 Very severely or extremely

Supplemental information* *Items are not part of NPI For all questions related to medication use, determine the drugID by using the drugID LookUp Tool on the NACC website at http://www.alz.washington.edu/MEMBER/DrugCodeLookUp.html
5. Is the participant currently on <font size = "2" color = "blue">dopaminergic agents</font>?
0, 0 No (SKIP TO QUESTION 6) | 1, 1 Yes (CONTINUE TO QUESTION 5a) | 9, 9 Unknown (SKIP TO QUESTION 6)
5a. Age at initiation of dopaminergic agents:
5a1. Age at initiation of dopaminergic agents?
5a4. Age at initiation of dopaminergic agents?

If the participant had no delusions, hallucinations, anxiety, or apathy reported in Questions 1 - 4, END FORM HERE.
Otherwise, if the participant has delusions (Question 1 is 1=Yes), then ANSWER QUESTIONS 6a AND 6b. If the participant does not have delusions or if the answer is not applicable (Question 1 is 0=No or 8=Not applicable), then enter 888=Not applicable for Question 6a and SKIP TO QUESTION 7.
6b. Delusions currently being treated with medication?
0, 0 No (SKIP TO QUESTION 7) | 1, 1 Yes (CONTINUE TO QUESTION 6c - 6d) | 9, 9 Unknown (SKIP TO QUESTION 7)

7. If the participant has hallucinations (Question 2 is 1=Yes), then ANSWER QUESTION 7a and 7b. If the participant does not have hallucinations or if the answer is not applicable (Question 2 is 0=No or 8=Not applicable), then enter 888=Not applicable for Question 7a and SKIP TO QUESTION 8.
7b. Hallucinations currently being treated with medication?
0, 0 No (SKIP TO QUESTION 8) | 1, 1 Yes (CONTINUE TO QUESTION 7c - 7d) | 9, 9 Unknown (SKIP TO QUESTION 8)

1a. How many months or years has this been going on? (months)

Form B8L: SCOPA Sleep - Participant

INSTRUCTIONS: This form is to be completed by the participant. For additional clarification and examples, see LBD Module Coding Guidebook for Initial Visit Packet, Form B8L. Check only one box per question.

FOR CLINICIAN USE ONLY
0. Is the participant too cognitively impaired (e.g., CDR>1) to complete this form?
0, 0 No (CONTINUE TO ADMINISTER QUESTIONNAIRE) | 1, 1 Yes (END FORM HERE)

PARTICIPANT INSTRUCTIONS By means of this questionnaire, we would like to find out to what extent in the past month you have had problems with sleeping. Some of the questions are about problems with sleeping at night, such as, for example, not being able to fall asleep or not managing to sleep on. Another set of questions is about problems with sleeping during the day, such as dozing off (too) easily and having trouble staying awake. First read these instructions before you answer the questions! Place a cross in the box corresponding to the answer that best reflects your situation. If you wish to change an answer, fill in the "wrong" box and place a cross in the correct one. If you have been using sleeping tablets, then the answer should reflect how you have slept while taking these tablets. Nighttime sleep In the past month, how often have you ...
1. Had trouble falling asleep when you went to bed at night
0, 0 Not at all | 1, 1 A little | 2, 2 Quite a bit | 3, 3 A lot
2. Felt that you have woken too often
0, 0 Not at all | 1, 1 A little | 2, 2 Quite a bit | 3, 3 A lot
3. Felt that you have been lying awake for too long at night
0, 0 Not at all | 1, 1 A little | 2, 2 Quite a bit | 3, 3 A lot
4. Felt that you have woken too early in the morning
0, 0 Not at all | 1, 1 A little | 2, 2 Quite a bit | 3, 3 A lot
5. Felt you have had too little sleep at night
0, 0 Not at all | 1, 1 A little | 2, 2 Quite a bit | 3, 3 A lot
6. Overall: how well have you slept at night during the past month? (CHOOSE ONE):
1, 1 Very well | 2, 2 Well | 3, 3 Rather well | 4, 4 Not well but not badly | 5, 5 Rather badly | 6, 6 Badly | 7, 7 Very badly
Daytime sleepiness In the past month, how often have you ...
7. Fallen asleep unexpectedly during the day or in the evening
9. Fallen asleep while watching TV or reading
10. Fallen asleep while talking to someone
11. Had trouble staying awake during the day or in the evening
12. Experienced falling asleep during the day as a problem

Adapted from Marinus J, Visser M, van Hilten JJ, Lammers GJ, Stiggelbout AM. Assessment of sleep and sleepiness in Parkinson disease. SLEEP 2003;26:1049-1054. By means of this questionnaire, we would like to find out to what extent in the past month the participant has had problems with sleeping. Some of the questions are about problems with sleeping at night, such as, for example, not being able to fall asleep or not managing to sleep on. Another set of questions is about problems with sleeping during the day, such as dozing off (too) easily and having trouble staying awake. First read these instructions before you answer the questions! Place a cross in the box corresponding to the answer that best reflects the situation. If you wish to change an answer, fill in the "wrong" box and place a cross in the correct one. If the participant has been using sleeping tablets, then the answer should reflect how s/he has slept while taking these tablets. Nighttime sleep In the past month, how often has the participant ...
1. Had trouble falling asleep when they went to bed at night
0, 0 Not at all | 1, 1 A little | 2, 2 Quite a bit | 3, 3 A lot
2. Felt that they have woken too often
0, 0 Not at all | 1, 1 A little | 2, 2 Quite a bit | 3, 3 A lot
3. Felt that they have been lying awake for too long at night
0, 0 Not at all | 1, 1 A little | 2, 2 Quite a bit | 3, 3 A lot
4. Felt that they have woken too early in the morning
0, 0 Not at all | 1, 1 A little | 2, 2 Quite a bit | 3, 3 A lot
5. Felt they have had too little sleep at night
0, 0 Not at all | 1, 1 A little | 2, 2 Quite a bit | 3, 3 A lot
6. Overall: how well has the participant slept at night during the past month? (CHOOSE ONE):
1, 1 Very well | 2, 2 Well | 3, 3 Rather well | 4, 4 Not well but not badly | 5, 5 Rather badly | 6, 6 Badly | 7, 7 Very badly

0, 0 Normal. | 1, 1 Mildly affected. No difficulty being understood. | 2, 2 Moderately affected. Sometimes asked to repeat statements. | 3, 3 Severely affected. Frequently asked to repeat statements. | 4, 4 Unintelligible most of the time. | 8, 8 Not applicable. | 9, 9 Unknown.

0, 0 Normal. | 1, 1 Slight but definite excess of saliva in mouth; may have night time drooling. | 2, 2 Moderately excessive saliva; may have minimal drooling. | 3, 3 Marked excess of saliva with some drooling. | 4, 4 Marked drooling, requires constant tissue or handkerchief. | 8, 8 Not applicable. | 9, 9 Unknown.
0, 0 Normal. | 1, 1 Rare choking. | 2, 2 Occasional choking. | 3, 3 Requires soft food. | 4, 4 Requires NG tube or gastrotomy feeding. | 8, 8 Not applicable. | 9, 9 Unknown.

0, 0 Normal. | 1, 1 Slightly slow or small. | 2, 2 Moderately slow or small; all words are legible. | 3, 3 Severely affected; not all words are legible. | 4, 4 The majority of words are not legible. | 8, 8 Not applicable. | 9, 9 Unknown.
<font size="3">5. Cutting food and handling utensils</font>

0, 0 Normal. | 1, 1 Somewhat slow and clumsy, but no help needed. | 2, 2 Can cut most foods, although clumsy and slow; some help needed. | 3, 3 Food must be cut by someone, but can still feed slowly. | 4, 4 Needs to be fed. | 8, 8 Not applicable. | 9, 9 Unknown.

0, 0 Normal. | 1, 1 Somewhat slow, but no help needed. | 2, 2 Occasional assistance with buttoning, getting arms in sleeves. | 3, 3 Considerable help required, but can do some things alone. | 4, 4 Helpless. | 8, 8 Not applicable. | 9, 9 Unknown.

0, 0 Normal. | 1, 1 Somewhat slow, but no help needed. | 2, 2 Needs help to shower or bathe; or very slow in hygienic care. | 3, 3 Requires assistance for washing/brushing teeth/combing hair/going to bathroom. | 4, 4 Foley catheter or other mechanical aids. | 8, 8 Not applicable. | 9, 9 Unknown.
<font size="3">8. Turning in bed and adjusting bedclothes </font>

0, 0 Normal. | 1, 1 Somewhat slow and clumsy, but no help needed. | 2, 2 Can turn alone or adjust sheets, but with great difficulty. | 3, 3 Can initiate, but not turn or adjust sheets alone. | 4, 4 Helpless. | 8, 8 Not applicable. | 9, 9 Unknown.
0, 0 None. | 1, 1 Rare falling. | 2, 2 Occasionally falls, less than once per day. | 3, 3 Fall an average of once daily. | 4, 4 Falls more than once daily. | 8, 8 Not applicable. | 9, 9 Unknown.

0, 0 None. | 1, 1 Rare freezing when walking; may have start-hesitation. | 2, 2 Occasional freezing when walking. | 3, 3 Frequent freezing. Occasionally falls from freezing. | 4, 4 Frequent falls from freezing. | 8, 8 Not applicable. | 9, 9 Unknown.

0, 0 Normal. | 1, 1 Mild difficulty. May not swing arms or may tend to drag leg. | 2, 2 Moderate difficulty, but requires little or no assistance. | 3, 3 Severe disturbance of walking, requiring assistance. | 4, 4 Cannot walk at all, even with assistance. | 8, 8 Not applicable. | 9, 9 Unknown.

0, 0 Absent. | 1, 1 Slight and infrequently present. | 2, 2 Moderate; bothersome to participant. | 3, 3 Severe; interferes with many activities. | 4, 4 Marked; interferes with most activities. | 8, 8 Not applicable. | 9, 9 Unknown.

10. Arising from chair (Participant attempts to arise from a straight-back wood or metal chair with arms folded across chest.)

0, 0 Normal. | 1, 1 Slow; or may need more than one attempt. | 2, 2 Pushes self up from arms of seat. | 3, 3 Tends to fall back and may have to try more than one time, but can get up without help. | 4, 4 Unable to arise without help. | 8, 8 Untestable.

0, 0 Normal. | 1, 1 Walks slowly, may shuffle with short steps, but no festination or propulsion. | 2, 2 Walks with difficulty, but requires little or no assistance; may have some festination, short steps, or propulsion. | 3, 3 Severe disturbance of gait, requiring assistance. | 4, 4 Cannot walk at all, even with assistance. | 8, 8 Untestable.

0, 0 Normal. | 1, 1 Retropulsion, but recovers unaided. | 2, 2 Absence of postural response; would fall if not caught by examiner. | 3, 3 Very unstable, tends to lose balance spontaneously. | 4, 4 Unable to stand without assistance. | 8, 8 Untestable.

0, 0 None. | 1, 1 Minimal slowness, giving movement a deliberate character; could be normal for some persons. Possibly reduced amplitude. | 2, 2 Mild degree of slowness and poverty of movement which is definitely abnormal. Alternatively, some reduced amplitude. | 3, 3 Moderate slowness, poverty, or small amplitude of movement. | 4, 4 Marked slowness, poverty, or small amplitude of movement. | 8, 8 Untestable.
<font size = "3">15. Modified Hoehn and Yahr staging</font>

0, 0 Stage 0 = No signs of disease. | 1, 1 Stage 1 = Unilateral disease. | 2, 2 Stage 1.5 = Unilateral plus axial involvement. | 3, 3 Stage 2 = Bilateral disease, without impairment of balance. | 4, 4 Stage 2.5 = Mild bilateral disease, with recovery on pull test. | 5, 5 Stage 3 = Mild to moderate bilateral disease; some postural instability. | 6, 6 Stage 4 = Severe disability; still able to walk or stand unassisted. | 7, 7 Stage 5 = Wheelchair-bound or bedridden unless aided. | 8, 8 Untestable.

Form B4L: Neuropsychiatric Inventory (NPI)1
INSTRUCTIONS: This form is to be completed by a clinician or other trained health professional based on co-participant interview. For additional clarification and examples, see LBD Module Coding Guidebook for Follow-Up Visit Packet, Form B4L. Check only one box per question. Inquire about symptoms the last four weeks before visit.

1. Does the participant have beliefs that you know are not true (for example, insisting that people are trying to harm him/her or steal from him/her)? Has he/she said that family members are not who they say they are or that the house is not their home? I'm not asking about mere suspiciousness; I am interested if the participant is convinced that these things are happening to him/her.
0, 0 No (Skip to Question 2) | 1, 1 Yes (COMPLETE Questions 1a - 1l) | 8, 8 Not applicable (Skip to Question 2)
1a. Does the participant believe that he/she is in danger - that others are planning to hurt him/her?
1b. Does the participant believe that others are stealing from him/her?
1c. Does the participant believe that his / her spouse is having an affair?
1d. Does the participant believe that unwelcome guests are living in his/her house?
1e. Does the participant believe that his / her spouse or others are not who they claim to be?
1f. Does the participant believe that his / her house is not his / her home?
1g. Does the participant believe that family members plan to abandon him/her?
1h. Does the participant believe that television or magazine figures are actually present in the home? [Does he/she try to talk or interact with them?]
1i. Does the participant believe any other unusual things that I haven't asked about?

1j. If the screening question is confirmed, determine the frequency and severity of the delusions.
FREQUENCY

1, 1 Mild - delusions present but seem harmless and produce little distress in the participant | 2, 2 Moderate - delusions are distressing and disruptive | 3, 3 Marked - delusions are very disruptive and are a major source of behavioral disruption (if PRN medications are prescribed, their use signals that the delusions are of marked severity)
1l. How emotionally distressing do you find this behavior?
0, 0 Not at all | 1, 1 Minimally | 2, 2 Mildly | 3, 3 Moderately | 4, 4 Severely | 5, 5 Very severely

2. Does the participant have hallucinations such as seeing false visions or hearing imaginary voices? Does he/she seem to see, hear, or experience things that are not present? By this question, we do not mean just mistaken beliefs such as stating that someone who has died is still alive; rather we are asking if the participant actually has abnormal experiences of sounds or visions.
0, 0 No (Skip to Question 3) | 1, 1 Yes (COMPLETE Questions 2a - 2j) | 8, 8 Not applicable (Skip to Question 3)
2a. Does the participant describe hearing voices or acts if he/she hears voices?
2b. Does the participant talk to people who are not there?
2c. Does the participant describe seeing things not seen by others or behave as if he/she is seeing things not seen by others?
2d. Does the participant report smelling odors not smelled by others?
2e. Does the participant describe feeling things on his / her skin or otherwise appear to be feeling things crawling or touching him/her?
2f. Does the participant describe tastes that are without any known cause?
2g. Does the participant describe any other unusual sensory experiences?
1, 1 Occasionally - less than once per week | 2, 2 Often - about once per week | 3, 3 Frequently - several times per week but less than every day | 4, 4 Very frequently - once or more per day

1, 1 Mild - hallucinations are present but seem harmless and cause little distress for the participant | 2, 2 Moderate - hallucinations are distressing and are disruptive to the participant | 3, 3 Marked - hallucinations are very disruptive and are a major source of behavioral disturbance. PRN medications may be required to control them.
2j. How emotionally distressing do you find this behavior?
0, 0 Not at all | 1, 1 Minimally | 2, 2 Mildly | 3, 3 Moderately | 4, 4 Severely | 5, 5 Very severely or extremely
3. Is the participant very nervous, worried, or frightened for no apparent reason? Does he/she seem very tense or fidgety? Is the participant afraid to be apart from you?
0, 0 No (Skip to Question 4 | 1, 1 Yes (COMPLETE Questions 3a - 3j) | 8, 8 Not applicable (Skip to Question 4)
3a. Does the participant say that he/she is worried about planned events?
3b. Does the participant have periods of feeling shaky, unable to relax, or feeling excessively tense?
3c. Does the participant have periods of (or complain of) shortness of breath, gasping, or sighing for no apparent reason other than nervousness?
3d. Does the participant complain of butterflies in his / her stomach, or of racing or pounding of the heart in association with nervousness (symptoms not explained by ill health)?
3e. Does the participant avoid certain places or situations that make him/her more nervous such as riding in the car, meeting with friends, or being in crowds?
3f. Does the participant become nervous and upset when separated from you [or his/her caregiver]? [Does he/she cling to you to keep from being separated?]
3g. Does the participant show any other signs of anxiety?
1, 1 Occasionally - less than once per week | 2, 2 Often - about once per week | 3, 3 Frequently - several times per week but less than every day | 4, 4 Very frequently - once or more per day

1, 1 Mild - anxiety is distressing but usually responds to redirection or reassurance | 2, 2 Moderate - anxiety is distressing, anxiety symptoms are spontaneously voiced by the participant and difficult to alleviate | 3, 3 Marked - anxiety is very distressing and a major source of suffering for the participant
3j. How emotionally distressing do you find this behavior?
0, 0 Not at all | 1, 1 Minimally | 2, 2 Mildly | 3, 3 Moderately | 4, 4 Severely | 5, 5 Very severely or extremely

If the screening question is confirmed, determine the frequency and severity of the pathy/indifference.
4i. FREQUENCY
1, 1 Occasionally - less than once per week | 2, 2 Often - about once per week | 3, 3 Frequently - several times per week but less than every day | 4, 4 Very frequently - nearly always present

1, 1 Mild - apathy is notable but produces little interference with daily routines; only mildly different from participant's usual behavior; participant responds to suggestions to engage in activities | 2, 2 Moderate - apathy is very evident; may be overcome by the caregiver with coaxing and encouragement; responds spontaneously only to powerful events such as visits from close relatives or family members | 3, 3 Marked - apathy is very evident and usually fails to respond to any encouragement or external events
4k. How emotionally distressing do you find this behavior?
0, 0 Not at all | 1, 1 Minimally | 2, 2 Mildly | 3, 3 Moderately | 4, 4 Severely | 5, 5 Very severely or extremely

Form B8L: SCOPA Sleep - Participant

INSTRUCTIONS: This form is to be completed by the participant. For additional clarification and examples, see LBD Module Coding Guidebook for Follow-Up Visit Packet, Form B8L. Check only one box per question.

FOR CLINICIAN USE ONLY
0. Is the participant too cognitively impaired (e.g., CDR>1) to complete this form?
0, 0 No (CONTINUE TO ADMINISTER QUESTIONNAIRE) | 1, 1 Yes (END FORM HERE)

PARTICIPANT INSTRUCTIONS By means of this questionnaire, we would like to find out to what extent in the past month you have had problems with sleeping. Some of the questions are about problems with sleeping at night, such as, for example, not being able to fall asleep or not managing to sleep on. Another set of questions is about problems with sleeping during the day, such as dozing off (too) easily and having trouble staying awake. First read these instructions before you answer the questions! Place a cross in the box corresponding to the answer that best reflects your situation. If you wish to change an answer, fill in the "wrong" box and place a cross in the correct one. If you have been using sleeping tablets, then the answer should reflect how you have slept while taking these tablets. Nighttime sleep In the past month, how often have you ...
1. Had trouble falling asleep when you went to bed at night
0, 0 Not at all | 1, 1 A little | 2, 2 Quite a bit | 3, 3 A lot
2. Felt that you have woken too often
0, 0 Not at all | 1, 1 A little | 2, 2 Quite a bit | 3, 3 A lot
3. Felt that you have been lying awake for too long at night
0, 0 Not at all | 1, 1 A little | 2, 2 Quite a bit | 3, 3 A lot
4. Felt that you have woken too early in the morning
0, 0 Not at all | 1, 1 A little | 2, 2 Quite a bit | 3, 3 A lot
5. Felt you have had too little sleep at night
0, 0 Not at all | 1, 1 A little | 2, 2 Quite a bit | 3, 3 A lot
6. Overall: how well have you slept at night during the past month? (CHOOSE ONE):
1, 1 Very well | 2, 2 Well | 3, 3 Rather well | 4, 4 Not well but not badly | 5, 5 Rather badly | 6, 6 Badly | 7, 7 Very badly
Daytime sleepiness In the past month, how often have you ...
7. Fallen asleep unexpectedly during the day or in the evening
9. Fallen asleep while watching TV or reading
10. Fallen asleep while talking to someone
11. Had trouble staying awake during the day or in the evening
12. Experienced falling asleep during the day as a problem
